back_matter.text: W. Zhou 1 , K. Geiersbach 2 , B. Chadwick 2 1 ARUP Laboratories, Salt Lake City, UT; 2 University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT. Introduction: Testing methods specifically developed for cytology specimens are needed due to the rapid expansion of molecular targets for diagnosis and treatment. Many tests, such as translocation detection by RT-PCR or next-generation sequencing, require the use of extracted RNA. RNA in cytology preparations may undergo severe degradation or modification during fixation, staining and storage steps. The quality and quantity of RNA isolated from cytology preparations are critical for downstream processes. We compared RNA isolated from DiffQuik stained slides using several commercially available kits. Methods: Direct smears were prepared from residual pleural fluid samples, DiffQuik stained, then covered with a glass coverslip. Slides were reviewed for cellularity by a pathologist or cytotechnologist. Coverslips were then removed by immersing the slides in xylene for 3 to 4 days. Cellular material was removed using a razor blade. RNA was extracted from a total of 15 slides using five different commercial kits: miRNeasy Mini (Qiagen), RNeasy FFPE (Qiagen), AllPrep DNA/RNA Micro Kit (Qiagen), RecoverAll Total Nucleic Acid Isolation Kit (Ambion), and Agencourt FormaPure kit (Beckman Coulter). The RNA concentration for each sample was evaluated using the Qubit RNA HS Assay kit (Life Technologies), from which the yield of RNA per slide was calculated. Amplifiability was evaluated by PCR amplification of the converted cDNA using housekeeping gene primers. Results: Among the 5 kits tested, the RNeasy FFPE kit had the highest yield of RNA isolated per Diffthe extracted RNA was similar for all five kits. Conclusions: Extraction methods vary among differently commercially available kits for RNA isolation. Cytology samples are not often specifically included in validation procedures and data are lacking on preferred methods for handling cytology specimens. In our series, the RNeasy FFPE kit was superior for RNA extraction from DiffQuik stained direct smear samples. The Cancer Research UK Stratified Medicine Programme 2 aims to genetically screen up to 2,000 non-small cell lung cancer patients a year to identify key genetic faults driving cancer growth. This genetic information will be utilised to match patients to their optimal treatment from the multiple "arms" of The National Lung Matrix Trial (run by Birmingham CRCTU and Prof Gary Middleton). Molecular analysis is performed at three national genetic laboratories in Birmingham, Cardiff, and the Royal Marsden known as Technology Hubs (TH). Methods: DNA from externally validated high quality cell line-based reference materials provided by Horizon Diagnostics and Illumina was analysed using a 28 gene custom Illumina Nextera rapid capture enrichment assay, sequenced on a MiSeq using V3 chemistry. Alignment and small variant calling was performed by MiSeq Reporter version 2.5 (BWA & the Somatic Variant Caller). Translocations and other structural variants were called by the Manta variant caller (v0.20.2). Results: A single panel analysis was performed at each TH and at Illumina containing nine high quality cell line-based DNA, a negative control and a blank. Promega DNA was supplied by Illumina, ALK-EML4, ROS1-SLC4A2, RET-CCDC6 translocation reference DNA, DNA from cell lines with multiple engineered variants at staggered allelic frequency (high quality DNA (HD701)) and cell lines embedded as FFPE DNA (HD200)) plus DNA with multiple engineered mutations at the same allelic frequency (Tru-Q 5%, 2.5%, 1%) was supplied by Horizon Diagnostics. The results of the analysis were shared for comparison. On first comparison it was found that results from the TH were not consistent. On investigation this was attributed to small variations in the bioinformatics pipeline used to perform the analysis. A WebEx tutorial was performed along with an in depth explanation of the analysis pipeline until the analysis was being performed identically at all TH. On re-analysis all TH and Illumina results were 100% concordant. Conclusions: A wet protocol for DNA preparation prior to sequencing and sequencing on a MiSeq is very consistent across sites, generating very consistent raw data. High quality externally validated cell line-based reference materials perform consistently across multiple sites. The most important finding was that seemingly minor differences in a bioinformatics analysis pipeline can change the analysis outcome significantly. Controlling the analysis is an integral part of a process if consistent results are expected through molecular analysis at multiple sites. Introduction: As the field of precision medicine continues to emerge from infancy, the birth of cell free DNA (cfDNA) as a significant diagnostic analyte for the next century is apparent. The first clinical utilization of cfDNA to gain prominence has been for the non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) for syndromes characterized by chromosomal aneuploidies. In blood, cfDNA is scarce and banking of significant quantities needed for ready use as reference materials, proficiency sets, or validation samples is not feasible. The aim of this study was to circumvent this inherent limitation, and generate a fabricated, patient like sample which approximates three key cfDNA sample characteristics: 1) sample DNA will contain a detectable chromosomal aneuploidy in either chromosome 13, 18, or 21; 2) sample DNA will be of the characteristic fragment size and fetal fraction percent; 3) sample DNA will be loaded into nucleosome mimetic requiring extraction consistent with a patient sample. Methods: Trisomic cytotrophoblast cell lines were cultured, karyotyped and the DNA extracted using conventional methods in order to obtain "fetal-fraction" DNA. Similarly, "maternal-fraction" DNA was obtained from a female, EBVtransformed cell line. DNA isolates were independently sheared to ~160 bp using a Covaris ultrasonicator then loaded into nucleosome mimetic. The desired trisomy, fetal fraction and DNA concentration were established by ddPCR at various control points in the preparation. back_matter.text: Introduction: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies are being integrated into clinical molecular diagnostics labs. This often necessitates bringing in highly specialized experts in informatics and NGS assay validation which creates additional infrastructure. Although the cost of sequencing has decreased, creating the NGS pipeline in house still presents a considerable investment of resources. Our goal was to develop a cost-effective clinical grade NGS infrastructure by utilizing in house talent and well selected outside suppliers in 6 months. Methods: NGS team was selected from existing molecular pathology staff (1 MD, 2 PhDs, and 2 molecular specialty technologists). Weekly meetings of laboratory leadership for planning to bring on NGS capabilities were setup. Survey of different disease-specific clinical sites was conducted for disease specific gene studies. The technical team was aligned to NGS assay development. Regular lab workload was redistributed to allow continuation of service. Illumina's MiSeq Dx was selected as the platform of choice. Three commercially available cancer panels with hot spot mutations (48 genes, 63 genes and 56 genes) were selected. Seventy six de-identified previously tested patient samples (50 FFPE, 26 blood) were tested. Departmental IT was consulted for networking and data storage needs. Results: Mandatory weekly meetings were conducted to keep the project on track and deal with potential issues (over/underclustering, poor specimen quality). Existing DNA extraction protocols proved to be adequate. Survey of the clinical sites revealed interest in diseasespecific targeted panels. Library preparation differed with the 3 methods; however all were easily mastered by the technical staff. Illumina MiSeq Reporter sequencing metrics and Illumina Variant Studio analysis showed depth of coverage greater than 92% for all 3 methods, with Q scores >30 and 90% of reads on target for most samples. The depth of coverage varied depending on sample type and target location. The minimum reads required was set at 100X for targeted bases. Single nucleotide variants and small insertions & deletions were detected. Several commercial databases were tested for result interpretation, and cloud-based commercial system was selected as best suited for our clinical needs. All three NGS assays detected mutations previously identified by single gene assays. Specialty pathologists and selected oncology colleagues were consulted about test report formats and information that needed to be included on reports. Conclusions: Support for therapeutic decision making requires quick turn-around times (TAT). We were able to integrate clinical-grade NGS process flow into our LEAN molecular diagnostics lab by retraining current staff. We expect to be able to meet TAT of 5 days to 7 days with the current as well as future targeted NGS assays. By leveraging existing skills and infrastructure, we were able to reduce costs and implement a flexible system that is well poised to quickly respond to changes in future developments and market demands. By partnering with commercial data base providers, we expect to stay current with evolving practice guidelines and choices for targeted therapy.

Introduction: Accurate characterization of the effects of base pair mismatches on nucleotide incorporation kinetics is essential for the optimization of allele-specific PCR protocols. A fluorescence based stopped-flow assay was used to study effects of mismatch type and position on extension kinetics. Methods: All oligonucleotides were HPLC purified hairpins and had melting temperatures greater than 88°C. All mismatched templates were based on 2 perfect match hairpins. The first had a 6bp loop, 14bp stem, and 25bp extension region whereas the second had a 6bp loop, 16bp stem, and 20bp extension region. We studied 9 mismatches at each of 7 positions on the two templates. Reactions were performed at 65°C and contained 50 /mL BSA, 100 nM template, 20 EvaGreen dye, and 5nM to 20nM Klentaq1 (dependent on position of mismatch). Subsets of templates were studied from 40°C to 80°C. Reactions were monitored on a stopped-flow instrument via fluorescence until saturation and data were scaled between 0 and the number of extendable bases per polymerase molecule. Linearity of apparent rate with both time and enzyme concentration was demonstrated on a characteristic subset of templates. Results: Rates of nucleotide incorporation ranged from 156 ± 6 to 0.03 ± 0.01s-1. Mismatches were inhibitory as far as 8 bases from the 3'-end. Within 6 bases away from the 3'-end mismatches were found to be 10% to 90% inhibitory. On average, a 3'-mismatch inhibited extension rates by 99.8%. Mismatch type, position, and assay temperatures were shown to have predictable effects on relative inhibition when compared across two sets of perfect match and unmatched templates. At 65°C, rates of nucleotide incorporation for 3'mismatches ranged from 1 ± 0.08 s-1 (T-G mismatch with the G on the primer) to < 0.03 ± 0.01 s-1 (AG mismatch). The relative inhibition between mismatch types was strongly conserved between template sets. The temperature at which polymerase activity was optimal was dependent on mismatch position. At the 3'-end mismatches decreased optimal extension from 68°C (perfect match) to as low as 55°C. At 55°C, rates for mismatched templates increased by as much as 200% whereas the rate for a perfect match equivalent was reduced by 40% relative to their respective rates at 65°C. Conclusions: Extension rates of mismatched templates vary significantly with mismatch type, position, and temperature, but in predictable ways across different oligonucleotide template-primer pairs. This study highlights the importance of primer design and temperature cycling optimization for allele-specific PCR. Introduction: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) is rapidly adapting to clinical testing yet raises some issues. In this presentation, we share some simple methods and experiences to solve some issues with QC and to maximize cost/manage efficiency. Methods: 1) 561 cases with MDS, AML or other myeloid conditions collected and DNAs were extracted. Myeloid panel developed withIllumina, covering all-exons of 32 genes, including all the hotspots reported. 2) Library preparation started with DNA 25ng/μL (or > 5ng/μL). QC Metrics generated by CGW pipeline. 3) RBC was lysed from blood and bone marrow to collect more myeloid cells, in cases that showed low yields of DNA. 4) A go-live modification for pooling 6 cases in one flow cell run instead of 4 cases was validated; the QC metrics of two pooling methods were compared. Results: 1) DNA yield: mean = 89.00ng/μL. Range: 7.56ng/μL to 443ng/μL. Library yield: mean = 73.2nM, range: 0nM to 300nM. 2) QC metrics: Among 557 samples, 42 failed to pass QC metrics ( Conclusions: Our data shows that mean concentration of library less than 22.2nM lead to QC metrics problems. Although DNA extracted is 15ng/μL or less, it makes mean library concentration 20.3 nM. As a simple and effective solution, more myeloid cells obtain after lysis of RBC thus increase DNA concentration to >15ng/μL most of time. Not enough DNA might lead to bias amplification during library preparation even starting with enough amount of the library in downstream process. How many samples to pool would be more cost efficient? Higher depth of coverage means more security, but more cost and longer turnaround time under current lab's labor and MiSeq availability. In myeloid panel run, 6-cases pooling in one run can balance the QC and efficiency, which cut 30% cost and turn-around time without compromising validation standards. P. Liu, E. Dimalanta, L. Chen, L. Ettwiller, C. Sumner, F. Stewart, T. Davis, T.C. Evans New England Biolabs, Ipswich, MA. Introduction: Formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) clinical samples are an invaluable source of information about genetic alterations in human disease, especially cancer. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) is a powerful tool to mine that information. Unfortunately, sequencing DNA from FFPE samples is challenging due to the poor quality of FFPE DNA, a result of damage incurred during fixation and storage. Additionally, there is usually limited quantities of DNA extracted from FFPE samples. In this study, we investigated the effects of DNA repair on library preparation and sequencing from FFPE samples. Method: FFPE DNA extracted from various ages of FFPE blocks from different types of normal or tumor tissues were selected for this study. A repair enzyme mix that is designed to work on a broad range of DNA damage including modified bases, nicks, gaps, and blocked 3' ends, was used to evaluate the effects of DNA repair on NGS library preparation. Each DNA sample (20ng to 1000ng) was treated with the DNA repair mix or was untreated prior to library construction. Library quality and quantity was analyzed on an Agilent Bioanalyzer. Control and DNA-repaired libraries were pooled together at equal molar ratio, and sequenced on an Illumina platform. Paired end reads were mapped to the human genome (hg19) using BWA, and base calling was performed by randomly choosing two million mapped genomic positions. The type and number of mutation events were calculated and normalized to the total number of each nucleotide. The randomization step was repeated 200 times. Results: DNA repair increased library yields significantly from FFPE DNA samples of varying quality, with the largest improvement on samples of poor quality. Yield improvements of 10% to 458% have been observed. Careful analysis of sequencing data shows that base calling qualities for all 4 bases were improved upon DNA repair. Aberrant G:C to A:T mutations were significantly reduced, consistent with cytosine deamination being induced during fixation and storage at room temperature. With DNA repair a noticeably positive impact on read mapping and read pairing was observed, resulting in the generation of more useable data. Conclusions: Treatment with the DNA Repair Mix increases library yields from FFPE DNA, improving library success rates. In addition, the repair process improves library quality with higher base quality, lower artificial mutation rate, higher mappable reads and higher properly paired reads. Furthermore, pretreatment of FFPE DNA by the repair enzyme mix is easily implemented upstream of library construction, allowing fast turnaround time and easy automation. We expect that these improvements will enable the analysis of many FFPE samples that would otherwise not be accessible.

back_matter.text: S. Grenier, W. Morrison, B. Nwachukwu, D. Maxwell, M. Mah, T.J. Pugh, C. Wei, T.L. Stockley, S. Kamel-Reid University Health Network, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Introduction: Historically, single gene approaches have been employed for molecular testing of solid tumors to assist in diagnosis, prognosis and guiding treatment for cancer patients. We validated the TruSight Tumor sequencing panel that targets critical exons of 26 cancer genes. One significant limitation of this approach is the lack of detection of insertions and deletions (indels) greater than 25bps in length using the default configuration of the manufacturer's MiSeq Reporter software. We sought to improve the detection of these larger indels with minimal changes to our technical protocol. Methods: DNA was extracted from 41 paraffinembedded tumor samples of various types, of which 10 had InDels ranging from 26bps to 51bps in length known from Sanger sequencing. We prepared NGS libraries using our validated Illumina TruSight Tumor Panel protocol. An initial alignment and analysis was performed, followed by a second alignment with a modified sample sheet in MiSeq Reporter with increased indel detection maximum from 25bp to 35bp, 45bp or 55bp. The variant reports from both alignments were compared to determine if the InDels >25bp were detected with the modified alignment and to ensure that the modification did not result in false positive calls. Results: Using the modified sample sheet, we detected 6 samples with known indels (3 deletions and 3 duplications) up to 51bp in length in the KIT and TP53 genes. In addition, deletions of 36bp and 31bp in length were detected and confirmed by Sanger sequencing in 2 previously untested samples. In 4 samples, we did not detect known KIT deletions which fell within the primer binding sites. No false positive variants were detected following the second alignment. The nomenclature assigned by the MiSeq Reporter software for InDels detected were not always accurate and had to be confirmed by Sanger sequencing. An additional 25 cases 6 of which have known indels are being tested and will be presented at the AMP meeting. Conclusions: Using the TruSight Tumour Panel, the detection of InDels up to 51 bp in length is possible with minimal changes to the protocol and with no additional false positive calls. To ensure accurate nomenclature, these indels may require confirmation by another method. There is still a possibility of certain indels being missed due to panel design. A similar approach may also be used to enable the detection of larger indels from data generated from other Illumina panels analyzed using MiSeq Reporter software. Introduction: Turn-around time (TAT) for diagnostic tests is often considered the most substantial measure of performance within a clinical laboratory. Manual purification of DNA from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) solid tumor tissues is a time consuming component in the execution of the JAX Cancer Treatment Profile, easily surpassing 8 hours for more than 24 samples. In this study, we investigated two automated Qiagen systems, EZ1 Advanced XL and QIAcube for the ability to improve TAT, obtain optimal DNA purity and concentration, and reduce repetitive motion injuries. Methods: Twelve (12) FFPE samples were extracted in triplicate; the first set was done manually, using the QIAamp DNA FFPE Tissue Kit, the second using the same kit and automated on the QIAcube platform, and the third using the EZ1 DNA Tissue kit for automation on the EZ1 Advanced XL platform. Purified DNA was further evaluated during library preparation and targeted hybridization capture using Aglient SureSelect Target Enrichment 200ng DNA input method and sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 2500. FASTQ files were submitted to a Clinical Genome Analytics (CGA) data analysis pipeline for quality metrics assessing mean target coverage and to generate concordance data. Results: Both platforms reduced the direct hands-on time of DNA purification; however the manual deparaffinization step was still required before each automated run accounting for 3.5 hours. Higher DNA concentration and yield were seen among samples purified using QIAcube compared to EZ1 Advanced XL. No significant differences between OD 260/280 purity ratios were noticed between sample pairs executed on each platform. Samples extracted by QIAcube and EZ1 generated similar readings for DNA concentration and yield after library preparation and hybridization compared to the manual method. The EZ1 was more time efficient when compared to QIAcube at 3.2 and 7.5 minutes respectively. No significant differences between the sequencing QC metrics of the samples purified on each platform were found. A 99% concordance was observed between the sample pairs processed on the automated platforms for actionable mutations evaluated by JAX-CTP compared to the manual method with overall TAT improved by about 1.5 hours to 2 hours. Conclusions: Both QIAcube and EZ1 purification platforms are capable of generating accurate and robust results. Performance of the QIAcube for DNA purification was superior to the EZ1 Advanced XL and resulted in higher DNA yield and concentration but slightly longer TAT per sample. Implementation of an automated DNA purification platform will reduce the risk of potential human error and injury and potentially add significant value to the execution and quality of results performed with JAX-CTP. Introduction: Biological reference materials for molecular diagnostics tests typically require cold chain logistics and storage for stability. However, refrigerated or frozen storage may not be available in resource limited settings. Even in industrial nations where cold storage is available, it adds to the cost and therefore limits accessibility of testing. To improve standardization and access to diagnostic testing, room temperature and elevated temperature storage of reference materials should be evaluated. SeraCare tested analytes such as viruses and bacteria at ambient temperature and elevated temperature in both liquid format and dry storage including lyophilization and ViveSTTM Sample Storage devices. Methods: Infectious disease reference material consisting of mammalian virus in commutable matrix was prepared and aliquoted into micro-centrifuge vials at 250μL fill volume. Some vials were lyophilized and stored at room temperature and 42°C. ViveST samples were prepared by adding 250 μL of virus onto absorbent matrix and allowing it to dry overnight. These vials were stored at room temperature, 2°C to 8°C and 42°C. At each time point, the samples were tested on an in-house developed TaqMan assay to assess the concentration in copies/mL. A similar approach was followed for testing the stability of Carbapenem-resistant bacteria and Chlamydia trachomatis. These analytes were tested on the Cepheid GeneXpert instrument to assess the variation in cycle threshold (Ct). Results: Comparison of results across different storage systems showed that virus was stable as lyophilized material and on ViveST absorbent matrix at room temperature (<2-fold difference in concentration across 5 weeks of storage). Surprisingly, the virus was also stable in liquid form (<25% difference across 5 weeks); this stability may be due to the proteinaceous nature of the matrix and the presence of an enveloped virus coat. Lyophilized viral material is stable at 42°C without decrease in concentration. Similar data was observed for bacterial analytes at room temperature for ViveST storage system and in the liquid state. These bacterial analytes are also stable at 42°C on ViveST storage system. Conclusions: To standardize and improve the quality of diagnostic testing, room temperature or elevated temperature stable reference materials for infectious disease testing are needed. In many African and Asian countries, temperatures of 40°C or higher are not uncommon. The stability of the virus and bacteria at 42°C in the lyophilized state or on the ViveST dry storage matrix indicates that these might be appropriate mechanisms for transport and storage. Adoption of dry storage in developed countries could also drastically cut cost associated with cold storage. Introduction: The Human Microbiome Project (HMP) is providing rich insights into the composition of our microbiomes and ability to maintain balance in specific tissues. Vaginal tissue is a rich environment where incidences of bacterial, fungal, virus or parasitic microbes can cause imbalance leading to severe impact at the site. Current non-molecular as well as molecular methods have limitations in sensitivity, specificity and/or have limited coverage and throughput for monitoring of microbes. Methods: We developed an in-house solution using our proprietary TaqMan chemistry for target identification and quantification, and OpenArray platform for spacial multiplexing of target-specific assays to address these gaps in vaginosis research. Our assays detect 33 microorganisms, including 20 bacterial (G. vaginalis, C. trachomatis, H. ducreyi, T. pallidum, Megashpera1 and Megashpera2, S. agalactie, and more), 7 fungal (C. albicans, C. glabrata, C. dubliniensis, C. krusei, and more), 3 mycoplasma (M. hominis, M. genitalium, and Ureplasma urelyticum), 1 protozoal (Trichomonas vaginalis), 2 Virus (HSV1 and HSV2) and 4 reference -Globin). Results: Each assay has been validated for specificity, sensitivity and detection efficiency using plasmid controls and purified DNA in presence and absence of complex genomic background with single tube analysis as well as on TaqMan OpenArray platform. We screened more than 200 samples from different relevant sources on OpenArray platform for multiplexed detections of microbes. Results were highly reproducible and were highly concordant with the results tested on different platforms or single tube qPCR tests. Results were also verified by orthogonal testing using capillary electrophoresis DNA sequencing and Ion Proton NGS platform with a very high degree of concordance. Conclusions: In summary, OpenArray platform in a combination with TaqMan chemistry can provide a multiplex real-time PCR pathogen detection method for characterizing the vaginal microbiota, with accurate results, simple workflow, fast turnaround time, flexible, and cost-effective high throughput. For research use only. Not for diagnostic procedures.

Comparison of the QIAamp DNA Micro Kit Against the Maxwell 16 FFPE Plus LEV DNA Purification Kit for Extraction of DNA from FFPE Samples S. Grenier, S. Santos, A. Kelly, W. Morrison, B. Nwachukwu, C. Wei, T. Stockley, S. Kamel-Reid University Health Network, Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Introduction: With the increased demand for molecular diagnostic testing on formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor samples, it is becoming increasingly important to extract higher yields of good quality DNA from small tumor samples. To maintain an acceptable turnaround time the efficiency of the extraction method is important. In this study we compared two automated extraction methods, the QIAamp DNA micro kit used with a QIAcube extractor versus the Maxwell 16 FFPE Plus LEV DNA purification kit used with the Promega Maxwell 16 extractor. Methods: FFPE material (curls, punches, macrodissected slides) was collected from 15 biopsies. For each sample equivalent amounts of tissue was split into two tubes. One tube was extracted on the Promega Maxwell 16 extractor using the Maxwell 16 FFPE Plus LEV DNA purification kit. The other tube was extracted on the Qiagen QIAcube extractor using the QIamp DNA micro kit. Modifications were made to the manufacturers' suggested protocols in order to maximize the DNA yield. DNA from all samples was quantitated using either a Nanodrop spectrophotometer or a Quantus fluorometer. To assess the quality of the DNA, we compared amplification products in various downstream assays. Quantitation results were compared for all samples. Relative fluorescent units (RFU) from fragment analysis assay results were compared for 7 samples and cycle thresholds (Cts) from Q-PCR assay results were compared for 3 samples. In addition, a time study was completed for both methods. Results: The DNA yield from the Maxwell extractions were on average three times greater than that of the QIAcube extractions. The RFU results from the Maxwell extractions were on average two times higher than the RFUs from the QIAcube extractions. The Q-PCR results from the Maxwell extracted samples were 1 Cts to 2 Cts lower than that of the QIAcube extracted samples. The total tech time required for the Maxwell extraction is 4 minutes per sample versus 17 minutes per sample for Qiagen extraction. Both protocols require a 24 hour incubation, after which the run time on the Maxwell is 28 minutes for 16 samples versus 60 minutes for 12 samples on the QIAcube. Conclusions: The Maxwell 16 FFPE Plus LEV DNA purification kit used on a Promega Maxwell 16 automated extractor provides higher yields, better quality DNA and reduced hands-on and total time for extractions than the QIAamp DNA micro kit used with a QIAcube automated extractor. After nucleic acid extraction, an aliquot is added directly to pre-plated lyophilized reagents and multiplexed RT-PCR and bead hybridization are carried out in a single thermal cycling program in a closed PCR plate. Upon completion, the plated is transferred to the MAGPIX instrument for reading, data analysis, and results reporting. In this study, we performed a preliminary evaluation of the workflow of NxTAG RPP as compared to our currently used method, the Luminex xTAG Respiratory Viral Panel (RVPv1). Methods: For evaluation of workflow, 24 samples were selected as representative of a typical run size and tested by both methods. Each step of the assay procedure, from sample acquisition to final result, was observed and the data collected include: number of steps, number of manual interventions, hands-on time, and total time. Results: NxTAG RPP had 6 total fewer steps and 5 fewer manual interventions as compared to RVPv1. The hands-on time was 22 minutes for NxTAG RPP as compared to 1 hour 13 minutes for RVPv1 and the total time for NxTAG RPP as compared to RVPv1 was 3 hours 44 minutes versus 7 hours 34 minutes, respectively. The steps and time required from sample acquisition to extracted nucleic acid are identical for both assays. However, from PCR set-up to reported result, NxTAG RPP required 6 fewer steps, 51 minutes less hands-on time, and 230 minutes less total time than RVPv1. Conclusions: The workflow is significantly improved in NxTAG RPP with only 6 manual steps versus 11 manual steps with the current RVPv1. The hands-on time is reduced from RVPv1 to RPP allowing more batches to be performed and reported in an 8 hours shift. By having RPP results available sooner to clinicians this can greatly decrease the length of stay for patients. Therefore impacting the entire institution where this is implemented. V.R. Bingham, Q. Ren, D.T. Merrick, G.T. Bocsi, D.L. Aisner University of Colorado, Colorado Molecular Correlates Laboratory, Aurora, CO. Introduction: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) is implementing Individualized Quality Control Plan (IQCP) as a new QC policy for CLIA regulated laboratories that will replace Equivalent Quality Control (EQC) on Jan. 1, 2016. IQCP may be used for Laboratory Developed Tests (LDTs) including molecular assays as an alternative to the traditional CLIA QC requirements. IQCP requires documentation of 3 activities: Risk Assessment (RA), Quality Control Plan (QCP), and Quality Assessment (QA). In anticipation of IQCP, the Colorado Molecular Correlates (CMOCO) Laboratory has developed updated QC and QA procedures implementing IQCP. Methods: RA for each assay included evaluation of the reagents, test environment, specimens, test system, and personnel across the pre-analytic, analytic, and post-analytic phases of testing. This began with an initial document review. Subsequently, a Fishbone diagram was created to identify potential sources of failure. A Sources of Failure (SoF) table was generated for eligible assays. Based on the RA, a QCP was defined for each eligible assay in the laboratory. A QA plan was developed to monitor the effectiveness of the QCP. Results: Fifteen (15) general sources of failure were identified using the fishbone diagram. Comparing each assay to this list enabled production of an SoF table applicable to all assays with 5 columns: where/when failure occurs, failure likelihood, failure causes, failure effect, data/documentation. The new QCP not only included a number of quality control mechanisms currently used in the laboratory, but also added test specific changes in procedure reviews, QC reports, QC review meetings, and troubleshooting guidelines. QA will include a comprehensive review system focused on each laboratory test and the specific related sources of failure. Each test will have a checklist of QA items to be monitored on a monthly basis and a plan for updating the QA plan when a failure occurs. Conclusions: IQCP can be an attractive alternative to traditional CLIA QC requirements for molecular assays. Current guidance on required IQCP activities from CMS and CAP is adequate to prepare for transition to IQCP. IQCP is a continuous process. RAs and QCPs require updates and refinement as new information and data are assessed. QA requires ongoing involvement across laboratory personnel from technicians running assays up to the laboratory director.

back_matter.text: Preparation from cfDNA D.M. Wilson, M.E. Carey, K.H. Hecker Rubicon Genomics, Ann Arbor, MI. Introduction: Cell-free DNA (cfDNA) in human plasma provides a minimally invasive path to genetic information by next generation sequencing (NGS). Within cfDNA subpopulations such as circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) or fetal DNA may be found. CtDNA holds promise for diagnostic and prognostic applications in oncology whereas fetal DNA in maternal blood is used for non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT). Prerequisite for accessing genetic information of cfDNA for any application is the ability to convert cfDNA reliably and reproducibly into high quality NGS libraries.Here we present an improved library preparation method that uses a wide cfDNA input range to generate high-complexity libraries with broad GC-coverage and other features relevant for diagnostic and prognostic applications on Illumina NGS platforms. Methods: Human plasma from 20 healthy individuals or pools was purchased from commercial sources. DNA isolated was characterized by Bioanalyzer and Qubit prior to use. The mono-nucleosomal fraction of the cfDNA accounted for about 20%. At least 3 technical replicates were prepared per input sample. Titration of pooled plasma cfDNA from 0.05 ng to 50 ng served as an intersequencing run control. Libraries were prepared using ThruPLEX Plasma-Seq, Rubicon Genomics' newest NGS library preparation kit specifically designed and optimized for cfDNA. 1.5 million to 3.0 million reads were collected per library. Reads were aligned to hg19. Results: For the input range tested, diversity of libraries was shown as the estimated library size (ELS) and was ca. 5x10exp8. Technical replicates showed very low variability. ELS showed some dependence on individual input samples and was slightly diminished at low (less than about 100pg of mononucleosomal cfDNA) input levels. Number of duplicates was below 1% and adapter rate below 0.01% for all samples tested. Chimeras were observed at a rate of about 2%. The average insert size was 167bp. GC coverage for pooled cfDNA from 10pg to 10ng of mono-nucleosomal cfDNA input was balanced and no significant deviation of GC coverage was observed for this 1000-fold input range. GC coverage curves normalized to the human genome for individual plasma samples did show some dependence on input samples with the bulk of individual cfDNA yielding balanced GC coverage. Conclusions: Hallmark of the method for NGS library preparation is an improved DNA repair reaction resulting in high-quality libraries with well-balanced, genome-wide GC coverage with little dependence on cfDNA input amount. Duplicate, chimera, and adapter dimer rates are low. The method presented here shows clear and beneficial improvements over currently available NGS library preparations. Introduction: Clinicians are increasingly relying on tumor mutation profiling via NGS to offer precision medicine therapies to patients. Labs need to establish and monitor the QC performance and lower limits of detection of driver mutations for their NGS assays. Reference materials that monitor one or a few mutations may give an incomplete picture as different mutation types (SNV, insertions, deletions and mutations within homopolymeric regions) may have different detection limits and may respond differently to suboptimal assay conditions. Additionally, variant calling and pipeline analysis greatly affect the quality of the final report, and reference materials that allow critical evaluation of software across a broad range of mutation types have been lacking. Methods: Mixed biosynthetic constructs were diluted into reference genomic DNA to form a highly multiplexed reference material bearing 26 cancer "hotspot" mutations. The mutations were in 22 clinically actionable genes and represented large insertions, large deletions, small indels, SNVs and mutations within homopolymers. Droplet digital PCR (ddPCR) was used to quantitate the synthetic and reference gDNA components to allow precise mixing at 20% variant allele frequency (VAF). Varying the mix ratios allowed creation of a panel at 30%, 25%, 20%, 15% and 10% VAF and we are currently extending this panel to lower frequencies of 2% to 5%. The material was tested on Ion Ampliseq Cancer Hotspot Panel v2, Illumina Truseq Amplicon Cancer Panel and a laboratory developed panel.

back_matter.text: The reference material had average VAF across the 26 mutations of 19.76% (standard deviation: 2.28%) on the Ion Ampliseq panel and 20.53% (standard deviation 2.08%) on the lab developed panel. ddPCR was used to ensure the 20% mutant frequency, but some discrepancies in NGS data were observed. For example, the PIK3CA p.H1047R (COSM775) had a depressed VAF on the Ion Ampliseq panel (12.9%) compared with the VAF on the lab developed panel (19.53%). This difference may be due to the mutation's location very close to the beginning/end of reads in the Ampliseq assay and points out differences in detection among assays. The panel showed the expected linear decline in VAF. For example, KRAS p.G12D (COSM521) had variant allele frequencies of 30.3%, 25.2%, 20.6%, 15.1% and 7.1% (R2 = 0.987). Conclusions: Highly multiplexed reference materials are needed to monitor performance and assess lower detection limits for a variety of mutation types and also verify the informatics pipelines used for analysis. Semiquantitative materials have been developed which may enable challenge of the lower detection limits and provide a more standardized method for quality control. Introduction: A kit for DNA extraction from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissues has recently become commercially available (Covaris, Inc). Although sonification of formalin-fixed tissues to augment the recovery of cross-linked DNA was first described more than 25 years ago, the release of this Covaris kit has reintroduced this approach to increase yields of amplifiable DNA for downstream molecular pathology applications. Here we compare the amount of amplifiable DNA recovered from a series of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissues using the truXTRAC FFPE DNA kit on the Covaris M220 instrument and the FFPE CSC DNA kit on the Promega CSC Maxwell extractor. Methods: Formalin-fixed, paraffinembedded sections of 7 colorectal cancers were reviewed to mark normal and tumor areas for manual macrodissections, which were performed in duplicate by a single technologist, leading to a total of 14 different cases. One set of tissues was used for DNA extraction with the Covaris kit and instrument while the other set was extracted with Promega reagents and instrument. The amount of amplifiable DNA was estimated in 2 independent BAP1 qPCR Sybr green assays targeting exon 12 (222bp) and exon 13 (536 bp) respectively. Standard curves, made from serial dilutions of high molecular weight genomic DNA, were used to convert Ct values to amount of amplifiable DNA. Results of the two protocols were compared. All tissues were from paraffin blocks of surgical pathology cases from 2012 and 2013 at our Institution. Results: Comparing the Covaris and Promega extraction methods, the BAP1 exon 12 (222bp) assay yielded similar amounts of amplifiable DNA; 10 DNA samples extracted using the Promega kit showed greater amounts of amplifiable DNA (median 2.5x; range 1.3x to 33.7x) and two Covaris DNA samples generated more amplifiable DNA (1.3x and 1.7x) (P = 0.06, Fisher's exact test). The Promega protocol generated more amplifiable DNA in all samples used for amplification of BAP1 exon 13 (536bp), (median 3.6x; range 1.2 to 15.2). The calculated median concentrations of amplifiable DNA at 222bp were 210pg/uL (range 24 to 3803) for Covaris and 344 pg/uL (range 63 to 4254) for Promega. When the DNA was amplified in the 536bp assay, the respective median concentrations of DNA were 32.2pg/uL (range 3.3 to 442) and 137pg/uL (15 to 1008) (P < 0.0001, Fisher's exact test). Conclusions: The quantity of amplifiable DNA recovered from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded material using the Promega CSC Maxwell instrument and reagents was superior to that recovered using the Covaris ultrasonification protocol in an assay entailing a larger (536 bp) amplicon, but the difference between the 2 protocols was only of borderline significance in an assay entailing a smaller (222bp) amplicon. Introduction: Although LCM has been used successfully with frozen and formalinfixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) samples, significant work has not been published utilizing PFPE specimens. Over 22,000 specimens have been preserved with the PAXgene Tissue fixative system for the GTEx project, many of which are heterogeneous in composition, and well suited for microdissection. As an ongoing quality control measure, GTEx RNA sequencing data is assessed by a clustering algorithm to confirm similarity among specimens of a particular tissue type. This review has identified a bimodal distribution for stomach specimens, unlike that seen for homogeneous specimens. An LCM pilot project has been initiated in order to test the hypothesis that this bimodal pattern is due to variable sampling of stomach mucosa versus muscularis propria, and to refine processing methods for LCM of PFPE material. Methods: PFPE stomach samples were chosen based on inclusion/exclusion criteria, including optimal block storage conditions, high RIN from corresponding PAXgene-fixed un-embedded tissues in stabilizer, and low autolysis ratings based on microscopic review. Block QC was performed to verify suitability for further use. Pathologists annotated reference slides to define collection areas, namely stomach mucosa and muscularis propria. Following LCM, RNA was extracted, QC'd, and distributed for sequencing. LCM processing parameters under evaluation include staining method, use of RNase inhibitor, collection time, yield, and extraction protocol. Results: On average, there was a 1.5 reduction in RIN value between PAXgene Tissue-fixed un-embedded and embedded samples, implicating an effect of the paraffin embedding process. In comparison, there was a negligible drop in RIN values when block QC was performed on frozen specimens. In a small subset of specimens stained by cresyl violet/eosin/methyl green or H&E stains (with RNase inhibitor) and collected by LCM, there was a further reduction of RIN value by 1.1 to 2.8. However, adequate yields and concentrations of RNA were readily achieved by LCM, and no technical impediments were observed. Clustering of RNA sequencing data demonstrates a comparable bimodal pattern corresponding to the mucosa and muscularis. Conclusions: LCM can be used effectively for RNA studies on PAXgene-fixed paraffin-embedded tissues. Despite a reduction in RNA quality due to additional processing and embedding, the yields and concentrations of RNA were adequate. RNA sequencing of differentially collected stomach regions allows us to attribute molecular expression patterns to mucosa versus muscularis propria, explaining the bimodal distribution pattern observed in non-microdissected tissue. Targeted Introduction: A major challenge in high-throughput, targeted next-generation sequencing of FFPE DNA is the ability to process samples of variable quality and quantity in standardized library construction pipelines. In clinical settings, improvements to success rates and turnaround times can have a major impact on patient care. Mechanical shearing is a major bottleneck in sample preparation for Illumina sequencing, as it is laborious and difficult to scale. To date, enzymatic fragmentation solutions (including tagmentation-based methods) have not proven to be robust with respect to DNA input and quality, and/or suffer from fragmentation and amplification biases that make it difficult to achieve the coverage depth required to reliably detect low-frequency mutations. Methods: We evaluated the new, singletube KAPA HyperPlus library construction method (Kapa Biosystems), which includes enzymatic DNA fragmentation with a novel enzyme cocktail. Fragmentation conditions were optimized for our established target enrichment workflow, which employs a custom Roche Nimblegen SeqCap EZ capture panel (FOrMAT) targeting regions of 42 genes associated with gastrointestinal cancers. Three pairs of DNA samples from FFPE and peripheral blood were subsequently processed using our previous workflow with Covaris shearing versus the new workflow with enzymatic fragmentation. Paired-end sequencing data were analyzed and compared with respect to key metrics, namely i) detection of variants at 5% frequency and above, ii) level of coverage at 100X, 250X and median depth, iii) percentage of unique, ontarget reads, and iv) percentage of duplicates. Results: The KAPA HyperPlus method performed similarly or better than our validated KAPA Hyper Prep library construction method with Covaris shearing. The frequency of variants detected above 5% frequency showed a high degree of similarity for all FFPE and blood samples. The level of coverage at 100X was comparable for all samples. However, at 250X read depth, the average coverage for enzymatically fragmented DNA was 15.5% and 20.5 % higher for FFPE and blood samples, respectively. Adjusted, average median coverage depth was significantly higher (1154 versus 328) for enzymatically fragmented FFPE samples, but similar for blood DNA fragmented with the two methods. The higher coverage for FFPE samples was primarily attributed to lower duplication rates, and only a small increase in the percentage of unique, ontarget reads. Conclusions: The KAPA HyperPlus workflow facilitates the production of high-quality libraries from FFPE samples of variable quality, in approximately 3 h (including fragmentation). Higher library yields correspond to higher diversity prior to capture, with distinct benefits for the detection of low-frequency mutations.

Grskovic 1 , D. Hiller 1 , M. Song 1 , B. Christie 1 , S. Wei 2 , J. Armisen-Garrido 2 , B. Edgeworth 2 , H. Amit 2 , J.S. Elechko 1 , J.P. Collins 1 , C. Chan 1 , R.V. Sit 1 , J. Yee 1 , C. Christopherson 1 , M. Nelles 1 , J. Sninsky 1 , S. Scott 1 1 CareDx, Brisbane, CA; 2 Horizon Discovery LLC, Cambridge, Cambridgeshire, United Kingdom. Introduction: Donor-derived cell-free DNA (dd-cfDNA) is a potential biomarker of acute cellular rejection (ACR) in solid organ transplant recipients. We designed and developed sheared cell line DNA reference standards to evaluate the analytical performance of a recently described dd-cfDNA NGS assay. The main objectives of the study were to characterize analytical test performance and determine the longitudinal variability of dd-cfDNA levels in heart transplant recipients with stable allograft function and in those who experienced rejection. Methods: Alleles of a panel of 266 SNPs were measured by targeted amplification and NGS to quantify reference standard DNA and cfDNA extracted from plasma. The reference standards consisted of cell line gDNA fragmented by sonication to the approximate size of cfDNA extracted from plasma. Trace amounts of DNA from one cell line were mixed into DNA from a second cell line at levels ranging from 0.2% to 12% and confirmed by digital PCR. An analysis pipeline incorporating open source and custom NGS bioinformatics was used. Precision (across runs, days, and operators), accuracy, and linear range were analyzed. To study biological variability, 109 plasma samples were selected from 24 heart transplant recipients who did not experience ACR during the study. To study correlation with rejection, 63 heart transplant recipients with biopsy graded rejection were selected from an observational trial (CARGO II). Results: The CV of up to 12 replicates per sample averaged 16.2% across the range from 1% to 12% DNA mixtures. Greater than 70% of samples were detectable at a mixture level of 0.4% trace DNA. The method accurately determined the dd-cfDNA established by digital PCR through the range tested for two independent panels, suggesting minimal proportional and systematic bias (slopes: 1.0 and 0.98; intercepts: 0.012 and 0.0011). In recipients with stable allograft function, the median dd-cfDNA was 0.79%. Between-patient variability (51% CV) was similar to withinpatient variability (45% CV). dd-cfDNA levels were significantly higher (p=0.017) in samples associated with biopsy-confirmed rejection (mean 1.7%) compared to samples from quiescent recipients (mean 0.99%). Conclusions: The precision and accuracy of a cfDNA assay for solid organ transplantation was demonstrated using custom designed panels independently verified by digital PCR. In the longitudinal study of non-rejecting heart transplant recipients, the within-patient and betweenpatient variability of dd-cfDNA were of similar magnitude and larger than the analytical variability of the assay. The dd-cfDNA was elevated prior to transplant rejection and therefore may prove to be a quantitative indicator of organ health.
